summary_points: 1. Cencora, Inc. acquired an 85% stake in Retina Consultants of America for $5.68 billion in January 2025, but incurred an additional $37.5 million in liability and expense related to the acquisition.

2. Revenue increased 10.3% year-over-year in Q1 2025 and 11.6% year-over-year for the six months ended March 31, 2025, but the company anticipates a loss of an oncology customer in June 2025, impacting future revenue.
3. As of May 7, 2025, $782.2 million remains under Cencora's $2 billion share repurchase program, and the company made a $100 million early principal payment on its Term Loan on May 5, 2025.
1. Mosaic's Q1 2025 net earnings significantly increased to $238.1 million ($0.75 per diluted share) compared to $45.2 million ($0.14 per diluted share) in Q1 2024.
2.  A liner tear at the New Wales Phase II West phosphogypsum stack has resulted in a $67.6 million reserve for repairs as of March 31, 2025, with potential for further unforeseen costs.
3. Mosaic exchanged its 25% ownership in MWSPC for Ma'aden shares on December 24, 2024, altering its financial reporting for MWSPC earnings.
1. Rockwell Automation's total company sales decreased by 6% year-over-year in Q1 2025 and 7% year-over-year in the first half of 2025.
2.  The company expects approximately $125 million in tariff costs for the second half of 2025, but anticipates these costs will be offset, resulting in no impact on earnings per share.
3. Rockwell Automation retired 40 million shares of treasury stock in the first half of 2025.
1. Devon Energy's net earnings decreased by $102 million year-over-year in Q1 2025, to $494 million.
2.  Devon anticipates a $1 billion improvement in annual pre-tax cash flow by the end of 2026, with $400 million expected by the end of 2025, driven by a business optimization plan.
3. Devon completed a $375 million sale of its Matterhorn investment on May 5th, 2025, with closing expected by the end of Q2 2025.
1. BorgWarner exited its charging business in February 2025, expecting to eliminate $30 million in annualized adjusted operating losses by 2026.
2.  First-quarter 2025 net sales decreased by 2% year-over-year, primarily due to currency fluctuations, despite positive volume, mix, and new business contributions.
3.  BorgWarner faces potential significant environmental remediation costs related to its PRP status at 16 hazardous waste disposal sites.

1. Johnson Controls is selling its Residential and Light Commercial HVAC business to Bosch Group for approximately $6.7 billion (JCI's portion), expected to close in the second half of fiscal year 2025.

2.  JCI's net sales increased by 3% year-over-year for the six months ending March 31, 2025, but restructuring costs of approximately $400 million over three years may materially impact net income in fiscal year 2025.
3.  Starting in the fiscal third quarter (ending June 30, 2025), JCI will use a new three-segment reporting structure (Americas, EMEA, and APAC).

1. Philip Morris International Inc. held its 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareholders on May 7, 2025, where the CEO highlighted the company's strong 2024 performance and positive outlook for 2025 and beyond.
2.  As of December 31, 2024, PMI's smoke-free products generated almost $15 billion in net revenues, accounting for 42% of the company's first-quarter 2025 total net revenues.

3. PMI faces various business risks, including excise tax increases, marketing restrictions, health concerns, litigation, competition, economic and political instability, and the impact of the war in Ukraine, potentially impacting future profitability.
1. Caterpillar's Q1 2025 profit per share dropped to $4.20, a $1.55 decrease year-over-year, primarily due to lower sales volume and unfavorable pricing.
2.  Caterpillar projects $250 million to $350 million in tariff-related costs for Q2 2025, impacting full-year 2025 sales predictions.
3. As of March 31, 2025, Caterpillar held $17.6 billion in unsatisfied performance obligations exceeding one year, with half expected to be fulfilled within the next 12 months.
1. Aflac experienced a dramatic decrease in net earnings in Q1 2025, falling from $1.9 billion in Q1 2024 to $29 million, primarily due to significant net investment losses.
2. Aflac anticipates a $311 million loss from foreclosing on transitional real estate loans.
3. Aflac's total notes payable and lease obligations unexpectedly increased by $253 million in Q1 2025, reaching $7,751 million.
1. Charles River Laboratories' net income significantly decreased to $25.5 million in the first quarter of 2025, compared to $67.3 million in the same period of 2024.
2.  The company expects $175 million in cost savings from restructuring actions to impact fiscal year 2025.
3. As of March 29, 2025, $549.3 million remained in their $1 billion stock repurchase program, with $350 million already spent repurchasing 2.1 million shares in Q1 2025.
1. As of May 3, 2025, all proposed directors were elected to the Cincinnati Financial Corporation board for one-year terms, and all other shareholder proposals were approved.
2.  The company declared an 87 cents-per-share regular quarterly cash dividend on May 5, 2025, payable July 15, 2025.

3.  Cincinnati Financial Corporation's operations face significant future risks, including those stemming from future pandemics, catastrophe losses, and intense competition within the insurance industry.
1. Disney's net income dramatically improved to $3.3 billion in the quarter ended March 29, 2025, compared to a $20 million loss in the same quarter of the previous year.
2. Disney faces a potential $5 billion payment to NBCU by the end of Q3 2025, depending on Hulu's valuation.
3.  A lawsuit filed against Disney challenges its fuboTV transaction, with a response due by May 28, 2025.
1. Dayforce's Q1 2025 revenue increased 11.7% year-over-year to $481.8 million.
2.  A 5% workforce reduction, completed by March 31, 2025, resulted in $29.2 million in restructuring charges with an additional $4-7 million expected by year-end.
3. As of March 31, 2025, Dayforce had $1.28 billion in performance obligations and $1.226.4 million in total debt.
1. BorgWarner exited its Charging business in Q2 2025, anticipating $30 million in annualized adjusted operating loss elimination.
2.  Adjusted net earnings per diluted share for Q1 2025 were $1.11, an 8% increase year-over-year, primarily due to higher adjusted operating income and a lower share count.

3.  Full-year 2025 net sales are projected to range from $13.6 billion to $14.2 billion, a slight increase from prior guidance due to favorable foreign exchange and tariff customer recoveries, but offset by lower industry production expectations.
1. Verisk Analytics acquired Simplitium Limited for $20 million on April 2, 2025.
2. In Q1 2025, Verisk experienced a 7% year-over-year revenue increase to $753 million, and a 5.8% year-over-year net income increase to $232.3 million.
3.  Verisk has $1,391.5 million remaining in its share repurchase authorization as of March 31, 2025.
1. Verisk Analytics, Inc. reported first-quarter 2025 revenue of $753 million, a 7.0% increase compared to the same period in 2024, and 7.9% growth on an organic constant currency (OCC) basis.
2.  Diluted GAAP earnings per share for Q1 2025 were $1.65, an 8.6% increase year-over-year; diluted adjusted EPS increased by 6.1% to $1.73.
3. Verisk reiterated its full-year 2025 financial guidance,  predicting total revenue between $3.03 billion and $3.08 billion.

1. On May 6, 2025, Charles River Laboratories International, Inc. entered a Cooperation Agreement with Elliott Investment Management L.P., resulting in the appointment of four new directors and the resignation of four incumbent directors, effective after the 2025 Annual Meeting of Stockholders.

2.  Non-employee directors appointed after the 2025 Annual Meeting will receive an initial equity award valued at $255,500 (before pro-rata adjustment), comprising 50% restricted stock or restricted stock units and 50% stock options.

3. The Cooperation Agreement includes a standstill provision restricting Elliott Investment Management's ownership to a maximum of 9.9% of Charles River's common stock and a non-disparagement clause until the later of 30 calendar days before the 2026 Annual Meeting's advance notice deadline or the Investor Director's departure from the Board.
1. Dayforce's Q1 2025 total revenue increased by 11.7% year-over-year to $481.8 million.
2.  Net cash provided by operating activities significantly increased to $49.6 million in Q1 2025, compared to $9.1 million in Q1 2024.
3. Dayforce projects full-year 2025 revenue to be between $1,929 million and $1,944 million.
1. Charles River Laboratories International, Inc. reported a 2.7% decrease in first-quarter 2025 revenue compared to the first quarter of 2024, totaling $984.2 million.
2.  GAAP earnings per share decreased to $0.50 in Q1 2025 from $1.30 in Q1 2024, while non-GAAP earnings per share increased to $2.34 from $2.27.

3. Despite overall revenue decline,  2025 financial guidance was modestly increased due to improved net bookings in the Discovery and Safety Assessment segment, primarily expected to impact the first half of the year.
1. CDW Corp's Q1 2025 net sales increased by 6.7% year-over-year to $5,199 million, driven by strong demand for various IT products and services.
2.  Despite a 9.9% YoY increase in Non-GAAP net income to $286.5 million, there's a significant $61.6 million difference between GAAP ($224.9 million) and Non-GAAP net income in Q1 2025.
3.  CDW faces risks from inflation, interest rates, and competition, potentially hindering its goal of exceeding US IT market growth by 200-300 basis points in 2025.

1. Trimble Inc. reported record first-quarter 2025 annualized recurring revenue of $2.18 billion, a 7% year-over-year increase and 15% organic increase, despite overall revenue being down 12% year-over-year (up 2% organically).
2.  For the full year 2025, Trimble maintained its guidance, projecting revenue between $3,370 million and $3,470 million, GAAP EPS of $1.43 to $1.64, and non-GAAP EPS of $2.76 to $2.98.
3.  Trimble's full-year 2025 guidance includes the impact of the mobility divestiture completed on February 8, 2025.
1. As of March 31, 2025, total sales were $4,432,000,000, compared to $4,376,000,000 for the same period in 2024.
2.  For the six months ended March 31, 2025, total earnings were $1,404,000,000, compared to $886,000,000 for the same period in 2024.
3. Stock compensation for the three months ended March 31, 2025, resulted in a loss of $59,000,000.

1. Rockwell Automation's reported sales for the second quarter of fiscal year 2025 were $2,001 million, a 6% decrease year-over-year, with organic sales down 4% and currency translation impacting sales by an additional 2%.

2.  As of May 7, 2025, Rockwell Automation updated its fiscal year 2025 reported sales growth guidance to a range of -4.5% to 1.5%, while reaffirming its organic sales growth guidance range of -4% to 2%.

3.  Rockwell Automation's Return on Invested Capital (ROIC) decreased to 14.2% for the twelve months ended March 31, 2025, compared to 18.0% for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, primarily due to lower pre-tax net income.
1. Vistra Corp. reported a GAAP net loss of $(268) million for the first quarter of 2025, compared to a net income of $18 million in the same period of 2024.
2.  Ongoing Operations Adjusted EBITDA increased by $430 million year-over-year to $1,240 million in Q1 2025.
3.  Vistra expects to complete ~$1.5 billion in share repurchases by the end of 2026.

1. Johnson Controls International plc reported strong Q2 2025 results as of May 7, 2025, including a 7% increase in organic sales and a 12% organic year-over-year increase in Building Solutions backlog, reaching $14.0 billion.

2.  Global Products Q2 2025 sales declined 13% year-over-year on a reported basis, but organic sales grew 8%, driven by price and volume increases;  the segment EBITA margin expanded significantly by 780 basis points year-over-year to 30.1% due to operational efficiencies and increased volume.

3.  Johnson Controls raised its full-year fiscal 2025 guidance as of May 7, 2025, increasing adjusted EPS before special items to ~$3.60 (previously ~$3.50 to $3.60) and improving adjusted segment EBITA margin to approximately 90 basis points year-over-year (previously more than 80 basis points).
1. Uber Technologies, Inc. reported $2.3 billion in both operating cash flow and free cash flow for the first quarter of 2025, a significant increase year-over-year.

2.  For the second quarter of 2025, Uber anticipates gross bookings between $45.75 billion and $47.25 billion, representing 16% to 20% year-over-year growth on a constant currency basis, but notes a projected 1.5 percentage point currency headwind to total reported year-over-year growth.

3. Uber's Q1 2025 net income included a $51 million net benefit (pre-tax) from revaluations of equity investments, while Q1 2024 included a $721 million net headwind (pre-tax) from similar revaluations.
1. Emerson Electric Co. reported strong underlying orders growth of 24% year-over-year for the second quarter ended March 31, 2025 (excluding currency and significant acquisitions and divestitures).
2.  Emerson's Q2 2025 adjusted segment EBITA margin expanded by 200 basis points year-over-year to 28%, exceeding expectations.

3. Emerson increased its full-year 2025 net sales growth guidance to approximately 4%, reflecting full ownership of AspenTech and a flat foreign exchange impact; however,  the outlook includes transaction-related headwinds of approximately $0.2 billion.

1. In Q2 Fiscal 2025 (ended March 29, 2025), Walt Disney Co. reported a 7% increase in revenue to $23.6 billion and a significant increase in income before income taxes to $3.1 billion, compared to $0.7 billion in Q2 Fiscal 2024.
2.  Disney+ and Hulu combined subscriptions increased by 2.5 million to 180.7 million in Q2 Fiscal 2025 compared to Q1 Fiscal 2025, with Disney+ alone increasing by 1.4 million subscribers.

3.  Fiscal Year 2025 guidance predicts adjusted EPS of $5.75 (a 16% increase over fiscal 2024),  cash provided by operations of $17 billion, and significant operating income growth across segments, although this is subject to macroeconomic uncertainty and potential impacts to business operations.
Failed to analyze filing
1. Cencora, Inc.'s fiscal year 2025 second quarter (ended March 31, 2025) revenue increased by 10.3% year-over-year to $75.5 billion.
2.  Adjusted diluted EPS guidance for fiscal year 2025 was raised from $15.30-$15.60 to $15.70-$15.95.

3.  International Healthcare Solutions segment revenue growth is projected to be 3-4% for fiscal year 2025 (6-8% on a constant currency basis), lower than the previous forecast of 4-5% (7-9% constant currency).
1. NiSource Inc. reported Q1 2025 GAAP net income of $474.8 million ($1.00 diluted EPS), compared to $344.3 million ($0.77 diluted EPS) in Q1 2024.
2.  The company reaffirmed its 2025 non-GAAP adjusted EPS guidance of $1.85-$1.89 and projected 6%-8% annual non-GAAP adjusted EPS growth from 2025-2029.
3. NiSource plans for 8%-10% rate base growth in 2025.

1. MarketAxess Holdings Inc. reported diluted earnings-per-share (EPS) of $0.40 for the first quarter of 2025, significantly down from $1.92 in the same period of 2024, primarily due to a $54.9 million reserve for uncertain tax positions.
2.  Total revenues for Q1 2025 were $208.6 million, a 1% decrease year-over-year, despite record Average Daily Volume (ADV) across several key areas.

3.  The GAAP-basis effective tax rate for the full year 2025 is projected to be between 41.0% and 42.0%, a substantial increase from the previous guidance of 23.5% to 24.5%, due to the Q1 2025 tax reserve.
1. Bio-Techne Corp's third-quarter fiscal 2025 organic revenue increased by 6%, reaching $316.2 million, despite a challenging macroeconomic environment.
2.  GAAP earnings per share (EPS) decreased to $0.14 compared to $0.31 in the same quarter of the previous year; however, adjusted EPS increased to $0.56 from $0.48.
3.  As of May 7, 2025, Bio-Techne initiated a new share repurchase program authorizing the buyback of up to $500 million of common stock.
1. Bunge Global SA reported Q1 2025 GAAP diluted EPS of $1.48, down from $1.68 in Q1 2024, and adjusted diluted EPS of $1.81, significantly lower than $3.04 in Q1 2024.
2.  Bunge is in the final stages of regulatory approval for its Viterra transaction and expects to close quickly once approved.
3.  Bunge's full-year 2025 adjusted EPS outlook remains at approximately $7.75, but Agribusiness results are forecast to be lower than previously anticipated.

1. On May 6, 2025, Frank Bisignano resigned as Fiserv's Chairman and CEO after his U.S. Senate confirmation as Social Security Administration Commissioner; Michael Lyons became CEO, and Doyle Simons became non-executive Chairman.
2.  Bisignano's departure resulted in the vesting of 153,787 and 57,127 performance share units (PSUs) for the 2023-2025 and 2024-2026 periods, respectively, with unvested PSUs forfeited.
3.  Information regarding Lyons's compensation is referenced from a separate January 2025 8-K filing.
1. CrowdStrike Holdings, Inc. announced a strategic plan on May 6, 2025, to reduce approximately 500 positions (5% of its global workforce), expecting to incur $36 million to $53 million in charges.

2. The company anticipates that approximately $7 million of the restructuring charges will be recognized in the first quarter of fiscal 2026, with substantially all of the remainder in the second quarter of fiscal 2026.
3.  CrowdStrike expects its fiscal 2026 first-quarter financial results to be in line with or above its previously issued guidance (as of March 4, 2025).
1. Cummins Inc. issued $2,000,000,000 in senior notes with varying interest rates and due dates in a public offering expected to close on May 9, 2025.
2.  The offering consisted of $300,000,000 of 4.250% Senior Notes due 2028, $700,000,000 of 4.700% Senior Notes due 2031, and $1,000,000,000 of 5.300% Senior Notes due 2035.
3. The Underwriting Agreement includes customary representations, warranties, covenants, closing conditions, indemnification, and contribution provisions.

1. Chipotle Mexican Grill hired Jason Kidd as Chief Operating Officer on May 19, 2025, with a $675,000 annual base salary, a 90% of base salary annual cash incentive target, and a $3,000,000 grant date value in equity awards.

2. Jack Hartung, President and Chief Strategy Officer, will step down from his executive position on June 1, 2025, transitioning to a senior advisor role until March 6, 2026, with a reduced annual salary of $200,000 and a 25% of base salary annual cash incentive target.

3.  Curt Garner will assume expanded responsibilities as President, Chief Strategy and Technology Officer, and Chris Brandt will lead menu and ingredient processes as President, Chief Brand Officer, with no immediate compensation changes.
1.  UnitedHealth Group's Q1 2025 diluted earnings per common share dramatically increased to $6.85, compared to a loss of $(1.53) in Q1 2024.

2.  The company expects to recognize approximately $12.4 billion in revenue from remaining performance obligations in future years, with half anticipated within the next three years (as of March 31, 2025).

3. As of May 7, 2025, a legal matter involving allegations of improper risk adjustment submissions and violation of the False Claims Act is unresolved, with the DOJ appealing a prior court decision favoring UnitedHealth Group.
1. Arista Networks significantly increased its common stock repurchases in Q1 2025 to $787.1 million, a substantial increase from $62.7 million in Q1 2024.
2.  Arista Networks announced a new $1.5 billion stock repurchase program on May 7, 2025, supplementing an existing program.
3. As of March 31, 2025, Arista had $3.5 billion in non-cancellable purchase commitments, with $3 billion expected to be received within the next 12 months.
1. AMD's Q1 2025 net revenue increased 36% year-over-year to $7.4 billion.
2. New U.S. export restrictions on semiconductor products to China are expected to result in approximately $800 million in inventory and related reserves charges for AMD as of May 7, 2025.
3. AMD's Q1 2025 net income increased by $586 million year-over-year.
1. Yum! Brands Inc. reported a 19% decrease in net income for the quarter ended March 31, 2025, down to $253 million from $314 million in the same period of 2024.
2.  The company faces a significant IRS tax dispute with a potential liability of approximately $4.6 billion as of Q1 2025, which includes a $2.1 billion underpayment, penalties, and interest.
3.  As of March 31, 2025, Yum! Brands had $1.4 billion remaining in its common stock repurchase program.
1. WEC Energy Group's Q1 2025 net income attributed to common shareholders increased by $101.9 million year-over-year to $724.2 million.
2.  The company anticipates retiring Oak Creek Power Plant Units 7 and 8 by late 2025,  with a net book value of $648.1 million (excluding deferred taxes) as of March 31, 2025.

3.  The EPA's 31 deregulatory actions in March 2025 could affect WEC Energy Group's future compliance costs and permitting, while Wisconsin's reclassification of ozone nonattainment areas as "serious" in December 2024 poses similar risks.
1. Coterra Energy's Q1 2025 net income was $516 million, a $164 million year-over-year increase; however, pro forma net income, assuming January 1, 2024 acquisition dates, was $547 million.
2.  Coterra completed two acquisitions totaling $3.2 billion in January 2025, with $18 million and $11 million of the respective purchase prices still outstanding as of March 31, 2025.
3. Coterra plans to spend $2.0 to $2.3 billion on capital expenditures in 2025 and bring 175 to 205 net wells online.
1. Corpay, Inc. reported first-quarter 2025 revenues of $1,005.7 million, an 8% increase year-over-year, with organic revenue growth of 9%.
2. Corpay is making a $500 million minority investment in AvidXchange as part of a take-private transaction, expecting the deal to be accretive to earnings in 2026.

3. Corpay maintains its original 2025 outlook, projecting total revenues between $4,380 million and $4,460 million, despite uncertainty regarding the macroeconomic outlook for the remainder of the year.
1. On May 6, 2025, the company declared a $0.25 per share cash dividend payable on May 30, 2025.
2. Wynn Macau, Limited (WML) recommended a final dividend of HK$0.185 per share for 2024, subject to shareholder approval on May 23, 2025.
3.  The company has a securities lending agreement with Goldman Sachs International for up to 459,774,985 WML shares, with 179,774,985 shares currently lent as of May 7, 2025.
1. On May 6, 2025, Expeditors International of Washington, Inc. declared a semi-annual cash dividend of $0.77 per share, payable on June 16, 2025.
2. The filing is an 8-K report, indicating an occurrence of other events and filing of financial statements and exhibits.
3. No specific future impacts or risks were mentioned in the provided text.

1. The company recognized a goodwill impairment charge of $1.153 billion for the Food Ingredients reporting unit during the three months ended March 31, 2025, due to its carrying amount exceeding its estimated fair value.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, the company had $711 million of available capacity under its Revolving Credit Facility, reduced by approximately $292 million due to commercial paper issuances.

3.  Subsequent to March 31, 2025, the company received $2.6 billion in gross cash proceeds from the sale of the Pharma Solutions disposal group and announced tender offers to purchase up to $1.8 billion of its outstanding Senior Notes.
1. Alphabet Inc. closed a €6.25 billion Euro-denominated bond offering on May 6, 2025, comprised of five different notes with maturities ranging from 2029 to 2054.

2.  The offering consisted of €1.5 billion in 2.500% notes due 2029, €1.5 billion in 3.000% notes due 2033,  €1.25 billion in 3.375% notes due 2037, €1.25 billion in 3.875% notes due 2045, and €1.25 billion in 4.000% notes due 2054.

3.  The terms of the bonds include clauses allowing for payment in USD instead of EUR if the euro is unavailable after April 29, 2025, and an option for Alphabet to redeem the bonds in whole, but not in part, if new US laws materially impact the cost of servicing the debt.

1. The provided text is an excerpt of an SEC filing containing only a list of URIs referencing sections of the Financial Accounting Standards Board's (FASB) Accounting Standards Codification (ASC).  No new information relevant to a business or financial analysis is present.
2.  No numerical comparisons are available.
3. No future impacts or risks are mentioned.

1. Baxter sold its Kidney Care business for $3.71 billion in January 2025, resulting in a $111 million net after-tax gain, and a $4.48 billion year-over-year decrease in total assets as of March 31, 2025.
2. Baxter incurred a $98 million pre-tax charge in Q1 2025 due to Hurricane Helene.
3.  Baxter anticipates future negative impacts from supply chain challenges and potential pharmaceutical tariffs.
